description.narrative:
IDEÈR FÖR FREDSFOND har ansökt om finansiering om 3 miljoner SEK av Sida för att utföra projektet ” FREDSFÖREBYGGANDE OCH PRIVAT SEKTOR I COLOMBIA-FIP 2017-2020” för perioden 15 november 2017 – 31 december 2019.
Projektets mål är att främja en aktiv roll av ekonomiska aktörer i uppbyggnaden av en hållbar fred i Colombia genom identifikationen och implementationen av konkreta handlingar och bidrag, baserat på affärsagendan för fredsförebyggande (inklusive komponenterna för ekonomisk stärkningen för kvinnor och miljömässig hållbarhet).
Projektets totala budget är 3 miljoner SEK, som Sverige kommer att bidra med till 100 %.

Ideas for Peace Foundation has applied to Sida for funding of 3 million SEK to carry out the project “PEACE BUILDING AND PRIVATE SECTOR IN COLOMBIA- FIP 2017-2018” for the period 15 november 2017 - 31 december 2019. The project aims at promoting an active role of economic actors in the building of a sustainable peace in Colombia.
The project total budget is 3 million SEK, of which Sweden will contribute with 100%.

description.narrative: The main objective of this project is to promote the active role of business actors in building sustainable peace in Colombia through four outputs or successive steps. First, identifying a baseline of initiatives and interests of the business sector at national level and three prioritized regions (Development Programs with Territorial Approach – PDET regions). Second, produce technical inputs and practical tools to encourage the role of business in peace building (Acknowledge and adapt). Third, to develop the regional peace building agenda (From words to action). Finally, to include participation of private sector in implementation of public agenda for peace, document and replicate experiences (learn and replicate). During the first year of implementation, FIP make significant progress in identifying business initiatives related to peace building in all the country. A database with 2.508 initiatives was consolidated, with key information about economic sector (industry, agriculture, mining, agriculture, services are the main sectors), municipalities-Departments (majority in Antioquia and Valle), type of leading organization (business foundation, companies, union, cooperatives). With this information the plan for 2019 will be to develop a peace research browser as on-line tool to systematize experiences and lessons. Also as part of the first step of diagnosis, FIP make progress in identifying business initiatives related to peace building in the three regions and the main business actors to work with. The criteria to define these regions were, first, conflict affected regions where a Development Program with Territorial Approach – PDET were planned. Second, economic dynamism in order to find relevant companies and/or chamber of commerce. Third, regions with presence of strong allies to work with. Based on these criteria the three selected regions were: 1. Sierra Nevada/Perija with special emphasis on Valledupar-Cesar. 2. Montes de Maria, with emphasis on Cartagena-Bolivar and 3. Cauca-Alto Patia and Valle del Cauca, with emphasis on Cali. In the three regions FIP established alliances with chamber of commerce, Governor’s offices and small and medium size companies and business associations from sectors of commerce, tourism, communication, livestock, agriculture. The regional dialogue allowed FIP to identify business priorities, conflicts and challenges, as well as opportunities to develop the peace building agenda. With this diagnosis, the second year will focus on deepen the peace building agenda within small companies and develop methodologies with practical tools for this kind of companies with lower or without sustainability standards. As part of the second step (Acknowledge and adapt), 32 representatives of companies from these regions participated in the forum “Business and sustainability: dialogue, decisions and cooperation” held in Bogota, on November 28 and 29, 2019. The Embassy participated in this event as well. The event was an important tool to identify and improve commitment from small and medium size companies in these regions as well as introduce dialogue about social, economic and environmental sustainability with a business language. The evaluation of the event showed high level of satisfaction among the participants. As a result, three promoting groups were established to continue regional dialogue during 2019 and continue to raise awareness among national-level business leaders and economic actors in the regions and to promote their active role in peacebuilding. The regional work is part of the third result, from words to action, that will be fully developed during 2019 with the regional promoting group as well as applying the Em-paz tool with small and medium sized companies. Finally, the inclusion of private sector in the public peace agenda (learn and replicate), made progress in dialogue about the fiscal mechanism of “public works for taxes”. FIP analyzed the first year of implementation of this mechanism through document review, interviews to participants, as well as focus groups with companies and the government. In addition, on September 18, 2018, more than 15 companies, implementers of or interested in the mechanism, participated in a seminar to evaluate and share experiences of it. As a result, FIP published a document with all conclusions and recommendations to the new government. This output was however affected by the change of central government in August 2018. One initial objective was to include private companies in the design and implementation of the Development Programs with Territorial Approach – PDET, issued from the peace agreement with FARC. During the first half-year FIP had dialogue with the Territorial Renewal Agency and developed manuals and guidelines for this private participation. Nevertheless, with the change of government, contacts also changed and the recommendations and guidelines developed by FIP were not considered. During 2019 the aim is to focus on the implementation of PDET in the three prioritized regions, with continue dialogue with the governmental institutions such as ART and the counselor for stabilization.
